An Analysis of Chattering Phenomena and Mitigation Strategies in a Sliding Mode Control Implementation for a Double Inverted Pendulum

AbstractÂ¶

Slidingâ€‘mode control (SMC) provides robustness against matched disturbances by enforcing a sliding motion on a properly chosen manifold. A major practical drawback of classical SMC is chatteringâ€”highâ€‘frequency oscillations in the control input arising from the discontinuous switching law. This report investigates chattering in a double inverted pendulum and evaluates four mitigation strategies: a classical SMC with a boundary layer, a continuous superâ€‘twisting algorithm (STA), an adaptive SMC that automatically adjusts the switching gain, and a hybrid adaptiveâ€“STA controller. We derive the system dynamics from first principles, describe the simulation methodology, and generate quantitative performance metrics (tracking error, control effort and chattering index). Simulations show that the hybrid controller achieves the smallest rootâ€‘meanâ€‘square error and control effort while keeping chattering moderate, whereas the classical SMC exhibits significant chattering and large control effort.

1Â IntroductionÂ¶

The double inverted pendulum on a cart is a canonical benchmark for underâ€‘actuated and nonâ€‘linear control systems. It consists of two pendulums attached serially to a movable cart; only the cart is actuated. Stabilising both pendulums in their upright positions requires counteracting gravity, coupling between the links and the cart, and unmodelled friction. Slidingâ€‘mode control is attractive because it ensures robustness to parameter uncertainties and bounded disturbances by driving a sliding variable to zero with a discontinuous switching law. However, the discontinuity excites unmodelled highâ€‘frequency dynamics and causes the control input to oscillate rapidly. These oscillations, termed chattering, lead to actuator wear, heating and audible noise and degrade tracking performance. This report analyses chattering in the projectâ€™s SMC implementation, formulates the mathematical model of the double inverted pendulum, and systematically evaluates four strategies to reduce chattering. SectionÂ 2 derives the equations of motion and defines the control objective; SectionÂ 3 describes the simulation framework; SectionsÂ 4â€“7 analyse each controller in turn; SectionÂ 8 presents a quantitative comparison and frequency analysis; and SectionÂ 9 summarises the findings.

2Â SystemÂ Modelling and ProblemÂ FormulationÂ¶

2.1Â Equations of MotionÂ¶

The double inverted pendulum comprises a cart of massÂ \m_c\ carrying two pendulums with masses \m_1\ and \m_2\, lengths \L_1\ and \L_2\, centres of mass \l_{c1}\ and \l_{c2}\ and inertias \I_1\ and \I_2. Let \x\ denote the cart position, \theta_1\ the angle of the first pendulum relative to the vertical and \theta_2\ the absolute angle of the second pendulum. The state vector is

x = \left\lbrack x,\mspace{6mu}\theta_{1},\mspace{6mu}\theta_{2},\mspace{6mu}\dot{x},\mspace{6mu}{\dot{\theta}}_{1},\mspace{6mu}{\dot{\theta}}_{2} \right\rbrack^{\top}.

Applying the Lagrangian formalism yields two coupled, nonâ€‘linear equations of motion (the cart dynamics is affected only by friction). For brevity only the pendulum equations are shown; they describe the rotational dynamics of the two linksÂ [1]:

\left( m_{1} + m_{2} \right)L_{1}{\ddot{\theta}}_{1} + m_{2}L_{2}{\ddot{\theta}}_{2}\cos\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right) + m_{2}L_{2}{\dot{\theta}}_{2}^{2}\sin\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right)\cos\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right) + g\left( m_{1} + m_{2} \right)\sin\theta_{1} = 0,
m_{2}L_{2}{\ddot{\theta}}_{2} + m_{2}L_{1}{\ddot{\theta}}_{1}\cos\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right) - m_{2}L_{1}{\dot{\theta}}_{1}^{2}\sin\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right) + gm_{2}\sin\theta_{2} = 0.

These equations highlight the strong coupling between the pendulums: accelerations of one link appear in the dynamics of the other. In matrix form the full model in the code is expressed as

H(q)\ddot{q} + C\left( q,\dot{q} \right)\dot{q} + G(q) = B\, u,

with \q=

$$x,\theta_1,\theta_2$$

^\top\, inertia matrix \H(q)\, damping and centripetal matrix \C(q,\dot{q})\, gravity vector \G(q)\, input matrix \B=

1,0,0

^\top\ and control input \u\ (force applied to the cart). In the implementation the matrices are computed by compute_matrices_numba in src/core/dynamics.py. The control objective is to drive both pendulums to the upright equilibrium (\theta_1=\theta_2=0\) while keeping the cart near the origin (\x=0\).

2.2Â Sliding VariableÂ¶

All controllers studied here derive a scalar sliding variable \sigma\ that combines angular positions and velocities. In the classical and adaptive controllers the sliding surface is defined as

\sigma = k_{1}\,{\dot{\theta}}_{1} + k_{2}\,{\dot{\theta}}_{2} + \lambda_{1}\,\theta_{1} + \lambda_{2}\,\theta_{2},

where \k_1,k_2\ and \lambda_1,\lambda_2\ are positive gains. When \sigma\ is driven to zero, both angular errors and velocities are driven to zero, ensuring the pendulums remain upright. The superâ€‘twisting and hybrid controllers use a slightly modified sliding surface but follow the same principle.

3Â Simulation MethodologyÂ¶

Simulations were performed using the Python environment provided by the project. The double inverted pendulum dynamics were integrated with a fourthâ€‘order Rungeâ€“Kutta solver (step_rk4_numba) at a time step \mathrm{d}t=0.001\Â s for a duration of \10\Â s. The initial state was chosen as \x=0\, \theta_1=0.1\Â rad, \theta_2=-0.1\Â rad and zero velocities; this represents two slightly perturbed pendulums. Each controller was tuned with the default gains from config.yaml and run under identical conditions. Actuator saturation was enforced with a maximum force of \150\Â N. Performance was evaluated using three quantitative metrics:

  • Tracking precision: the rootâ€‘meanâ€‘square error (RMSE) of \(\theta_1,\theta_2)\ from the upright position.

  • Control effort: the integral of the squared control input \int u(t)^2\mathrm{d}t.

  • Chattering index: the total variation of the control signal \sum_{i}|u_{i+1}-u_i|\, which measures highâ€‘frequency oscillations.

In addition, the control signals were analysed in the frequency domain using the discrete Fourier transform to visualise how mitigation strategies shift energy to lower frequencies.

4Â Classic SlidingÂ Mode ControlÂ¶

4.1Â Origin of ChatteringÂ¶

Classical SMC splits the control law into an equivalent term that cancels the nominal dynamics and a switching term that rejects disturbances. The switching term uses a discontinuous sign function \mathrm{sgn}(\sigma)\ to force the sliding variable toward zero. Any sampling delay, actuator lag or unmodelled highâ€‘frequency dynamics prevents the system from following the ideal discontinuous control and instead produces rapid oscillations. The switching gain \K\ must exceed the disturbance bound to guarantee robustness, but a larger gain amplifies the amplitude of these oscillations. Chattering therefore arises from the combination of a discontinuous control law and practical limitations in sensors and actuators.

Chattering arises because any sampling delay, actuator lag or unmodelled fast dynamics prevents the plant from following the ideal discontinuous control and instead produces oscillations with finite frequency and amplitude; furthermore, the amplitude of these oscillations is proportional to the magnitude of the discontinuous switching termÂ [3].

4.2Â Implementation and Boundary Layer ApproximationÂ¶

In the project (src/controllers/classic_smc.py) the sliding surface is implemented as a linear combination of joint angles and velocities. The equivalent control \u_{\mathrm{eq}}\ is computed by inverting the inertia matrix \H(q)\; the switching term uses a continuous approximation of the sign function implemented in src/utils/control_primitives.py as the saturation function

sat(\sigma/\epsilon) = \left\{ \begin{matrix}
\tanh(\sigma/\epsilon), & \text{if method~=~â€œtanhâ€}, \\
clip(\sigma/\epsilon, - 1,1), & \text{if method~=~â€œlinearâ€},
\end{matrix} \right.\

where \epsilon>0\ is the boundaryâ€‘layer width. A smaller \epsilon\ yields a steeper transition and better accuracy but reâ€‘introduces chattering; a larger \epsilon\ smooths the control but causes a steadyâ€‘state error because the system state is only guaranteed to converge to \|\sigma| \le \epsilon.

4.3Â Physical Consequences of ChatteringÂ¶

Chattering is not merely a numerical artifact. Rapid switching of the control signal can excite unmodelled flexible modes of the mechanical structure, leading to vibrations and audible noise. In electrical drives the highâ€‘frequency current reversals cause excessive heat generation in power electronics. Mechanical components such as bearings and gears experience increased wear due to microâ€‘vibrations. Therefore chattering reduction is crucial when implementing SMC on real hardware.

Chattering in slidingâ€‘mode control also leads to low control accuracy and causes high wear of mechanical components and heat losses in power electronicsÂ [3].

4.4Â Visualisation of ChatteringÂ¶

FigureÂ 1 presents the control input of the classical SMC and illustrates the highâ€‘frequency oscillations characteristic of chattering. FigureÂ 2 shows the corresponding sliding variable oscillating around zero. These plots were generated from the simulation described in SectionÂ 3.

Control input of classical SMC showing highâ€‘frequency oscillations

FigureÂ 1: Control input \u(t)\ for the classical SMC. Rapid switching between positive and negative values indicates chattering.

Sliding variable of classical SMC oscillating around zero

FigureÂ 2: Sliding variable \sigma(t)\ for the classical SMC. The oscillations around zero correspond to the control chattering.

5Â ChatteringÂ Mitigation StrategyÂ I:Â BoundaryÂ LayerÂ MethodÂ¶

The simplest way to reduce chattering is to replace the discontinuous sign function by the continuous saturation function defined in SectionÂ 4. Inside a boundary layer of width \epsilon\, the control law becomes linear in \sigma\; outside the boundary layer it behaves like the sign function. This method reduces highâ€‘frequency oscillations but introduces a steadyâ€‘state error because the system converges only to the set \{\sigma:|\sigma|\le\epsilon}. Tuning \epsilon\ is therefore a tradeâ€‘off: a smaller boundary layer improves precision at the cost of increased chattering, whereas a larger layer smooths the control but reduces accuracy. In practice \epsilon\ is chosen based on actuator bandwidth and allowable tracking error.

Smooth approximations of the sign function, such as Slotineâ€™s boundary layer method or nonlinear saturation functions, reduce highâ€‘frequency oscillations but introduce a steadyâ€‘state error proportional to the boundaryâ€‘layer widthÂ [4,Â 5,Â 6].

6Â ChatteringÂ Mitigation StrategyÂ II:Â Superâ€‘Twisting AlgorithmÂ¶

6.1Â Standard Formulation and Mapping to CodeÂ¶

The superâ€‘twisting algorithm (STA) is a secondâ€‘order sliding mode technique that yields a continuous control input. The STA introduces an additional internal variable \z\ and defines the control law

\begin{matrix}
u & = u_{eq} - K_{1}\,\sqrt{|\sigma|}\, sgn(\sigma) + z - d\,\sigma, \\
\dot{z} & = - K_{2}\, sgn(\sigma),
\end{matrix}

where \K_1\ and \K_2\ are algorithmic gains and \d\ge 0\ is an optional damping gain. The discontinuous sign function only appears inside an integrator (\dot{z}\), so the control input \u\ remains continuous. In the code (src/controllers/sta_smc.py) these variables correspond to alg_gain_K1 (\K_1\), alg_gain_K2 (\K_2\), surf_gain_k1,k2 and surf_lam1,lam2 (slidingâ€‘surface gains) and damping_gain (\d\). The boundary layer parameter boundary_layer implements a saturated sign, ensuring finiteâ€‘time convergence in discreteâ€‘time implementations.

Higherâ€‘order sliding modes such as the superâ€‘twisting algorithm preserve the robustness of classical SMC while providing nearly chatterâ€‘free continuous control actionsÂ [7].

6.2Â Visual Comparison with Classical SMCÂ¶

FigureÂ 3 compares the control input generated by the superâ€‘twisting algorithm with the classical SMC. The STA produces a smooth control signal with no rapid sign changes, demonstrating the effectiveness of the secondâ€‘order sliding mode in eliminating chattering.

Comparison of control inputs: classical SMC (chattering) vs superâ€‘twisting SMC (smooth)

FigureÂ 3: Overlay of control inputs for classical SMC (orange) and superâ€‘twisting SMC (blue). The STA removes highâ€‘frequency oscillations and yields a continuous control signal.

7Â ChatteringÂ Mitigation StrategyÂ III:Â AdaptiveÂ SlidingÂ ModeÂ ControlÂ¶

7.1Â Motivation and Control LawÂ¶

A drawback of classical SMC is the need to choose a switching gain \K\ larger than the unknown disturbance bound. If \K\ is chosen too small the controller loses robustness; if it is chosen too large it aggravates chattering. Adaptive slidingâ€‘mode control addresses this problem by adjusting the gain online based on the observed sliding variable. The adaptive controller in src/controllers/adaptive_smc.py computes the sliding variable as in the classical case and uses the control law

u = u_{eq} - K\, sat(\sigma/\epsilon) - \alpha\,\sigma,

where \alpha>0\ adds linear damping. The gain \K\ evolves according to an adaptation law

\dot{K} = \gamma\,|\sigma| - \text{leak}\,\left( K - K_{0} \right),

subject to \K_{\min}\le K \le K_{\max}\ and a rate limit. When \|\sigma|\ is large, \K\ increases to enhance robustness; when \|\sigma|\ is small (below a deadâ€‘zone threshold), the leak term drives \K\ back toward its initial value \K_0. This method eliminates the need for a priori knowledge of disturbance bounds.

7.2Â Gain Adaptation VisualisationÂ¶

FigureÂ 4 illustrates how the adaptive gain \K(t)\ evolves during a simulation. The gain increases when the sliding variable is large and decays when the system is near the sliding surface. FigureÂ 5 shows the corresponding sliding variable. These plots demonstrate that the adaptive law suppresses chattering by raising the switching gain only when necessary.

Adaptive gain K(t) increasing when |Ïƒ| is large and decreasing in the dead zone

FigureÂ 4: Evolution of the adaptive gain \K(t)\ in the adaptive SMC controller.

Sliding variable Ïƒ(t) under adaptive SMC

FigureÂ 5: Sliding variable \sigma(t)\ under the adaptive SMC controller. Chattering is significantly reduced compared with the classical case.

8Â ChatteringÂ Mitigation StrategyÂ IV:Â HybridÂ Adaptiveâ€“STAÂ¶

The hybrid controller in src/controllers/hybrid_adaptive_sta_smc.py combines the continuous superâ€‘twisting algorithm with stateâ€‘dependent gain adaptation. The sliding surface includes relative angles to decouple the second pendulum. Two gains \k_1\ and \k_2\ multiply the superâ€‘twisting continuous and integral terms, respectively, and are adapted according to

{\dot{k}}_{1} = \gamma_{1}\,|s| - \ell_{1}\,\left( k_{1} - k_{1,0} \right),\quad\quad{\dot{k}}_{2} = \gamma_{2}\,|s| - \ell_{2}\,\left( k_{2} - k_{2,0} \right),

where \ell_1,\ell_2\ are leak rates and \k_{1,0},k_{2,0}\ initial gains. Adaptation is frozen when the sliding variable \|s|\ falls below a deadâ€‘zone. An additional PD term recentres the cart. By combining adaptive gains with a secondâ€‘order sliding mode, the hybrid controller achieves rapid convergence without prior knowledge of disturbance bounds and maintains a continuous control inputÂ [8].

9Â SynthesisÂ and Comparative AnalysisÂ¶

9.1Â Quantitative ResultsÂ¶

TableÂ 1 summarises the simulation results for the four controllers. The classical controller exhibits moderate tracking precision but requires a very large control effort and still shows a nonâ€‘zero chattering index. The superâ€‘twisting controller removes chattering but performs poorly with the default gains, resulting in large errors. The adaptive SMC improves robustness by increasing its gain but still struggles to stabilise both pendulums. The hybrid adaptiveâ€“STA achieves the best precision and minimal control effort while keeping the chattering index at a manageable level.

9.2Â Frequency AnalysisÂ¶

To visualise how the mitigation strategies shift control energy to lower frequencies, the power spectra of the control inputs were computed using the discrete Fourier transform. FigureÂ 6 plots the magnitude of the Fourier transform of \u(t)\ for all controllers. The classical SMC shows significant highâ€‘frequency content due to chattering. The superâ€‘twisting and hybrid controllers concentrate energy at lower frequencies, demonstrating that replacing the discontinuous switching law by an integrated law effectively removes highâ€‘frequency oscillations. The adaptive controller reduces the highâ€‘frequency content compared with the classical case but still contains moderate energy at high frequencies.

Frequency spectra of control signals for all controllers

FigureÂ 6: Discrete Fourier transform magnitudes of the control signals for the classical SMC, superâ€‘twisting SMC, adaptive SMC and hybrid adaptiveâ€“STA controllers. Mitigation strategies shift control energy to lower frequencies, thereby reducing chattering.

9.3Â DiscussionÂ¶

The results reveal that chattering originates from the discontinuous switching term in classical slidingâ€‘mode control. Introducing a boundary layer smooths the control but inevitably leads to a steadyâ€‘state error. The superâ€‘twisting algorithm removes chattering by integrating the discontinuous term and achieves finiteâ€‘time convergence; however, appropriate tuning of the algorithmic gains is necessary for good tracking performance. Adaptive SMC eliminates the need for a priori disturbance bounds by increasing the switching gain when the sliding variable is large and decreasing it near the sliding surface; this yields a continuous control signal and reduces chattering. The hybrid adaptiveâ€“STA combines the advantages of both adaptive gain adjustment and the superâ€‘twisting algorithm. In the simulations it achieved the lowest tracking error and control effort while keeping the chattering index moderate. Thus, for applications requiring precise control and smooth actuation, the hybrid adaptiveâ€“STA controller is the preferred strategy.
